title-group.article-title: Feed-forward inverse control for transient waveform replication on electro-hydraulic shaking table

article-meta.aff: 1School of Mechanical and Electrical Engineering, China University of Mining and Technology, Xuzhou, People’s Republic of China
2School of Mechatronics Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Gang Shen, School of Mechanical and Electrical Engineering, China University of Mining and Technology, Xuzhou, Jiangsu, 221116, People’s Republic of China Email: shenganghit@163.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this paper, an improved feed-forward inverse control scheme is proposed for transient waveform replication (TWR) on an electro-hydraulic shaking table (EHST). TWR is to determine whether a test article can remain operational and retain its structural integrity when subjected to a specific shock and vibration environment. Feed-forward inverse transfer function compensation is a useful technique to improve the tracking accuracy of the TWR on the EHST system due to their inherent hydraulic dynamics. Whenever a feed-forward inverse transfer function is employed, it is critical to design the identification accuracy of the inverse transfer function. A combined control strategy, which combines a feed-forward inverse transfer function compensation approach with a simple internal model control (IMC) and a real-time feedback controller, is proposed to minimize the effect of the system uncertainty and modeling error, and further to improve the tracking accuracy of the TWR. Thus, the proposed control strategy combines the merits of feed-forward inverse transfer function compensation and IMC. The procedure of the proposed control strategy is programmed in MATLAB/Simulink, and then is compiled to a real-time PC with Microsoft Visual Studio.NET for implementation. Simulation and experimental results demonstrated the viability of the proposed combined control strategy.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The electro-hydraulic shaking table (EHST) is one of the most important pieces to replicate real-time actual situations in civil and architectural engineering (Ji et al., 2009), the automotive industry (Kim et al., 2008; Plummer, 2011) and earthquake resistance testing (Severn, 2011), etc. The objective of transient waveform replication (TWR) is to determine whether a test article can remain operational and retain its structural integrity when subjected to a specific shock and vibration environment (Underwood et al., 2001).

An EHST servo control system without any compensation control strategies can be represented by the block diagram in Figure 1. The system it is wished to control is labeled controlled plant including three pieces: servo-valve and its controller, servo-hydraulic actuator and EHST. Figure 1.
Block diagram representation of an electro-hydraulic shaking table system without any compensation.

Reference transient waveform (RTW) in Figure 1 is the desired transient waveform signal, which can be defined as a classical shock waveform including half-sine, pre-sawtooth, post-sawtooth, and rectangular. It can also be defined as a seismic synthesis waveform (SSW) by a shock response spectrum (SRS). The EHST system is designed based on a closed-loop position, but usually, the EHST’s motion is given by acceleration data. So, a reference signal generator (Ref_sig_gen in Figure 1) is employed to take the acceleration reference signal to generate an expected position drive signal. Therefore, TWR can be formulated as a position tracking control problem described inFigure 1. The reference position (Ref Disp in Figure 1) could be used as the reference command of the position feedback closed-loop. However, the position and acceleration output response of the EHST system would not be intended in its magnitude and phase if there are not any compensation for the EHST dynamic characteristics because it may be caused by several factors such as physical system parameters and the dynamic characteristics of the payload (Thomas and Donald, 1997).

Various compensation control strategies have beenproposed to obtain the best fidelity waveform replication results by compensating for its dynamic characteristics. MTS Systems Corporation developed a commercial package named Remote Parameter Control (RPC) in 1977, which was widely used in the automotive industry and the inverse transfer function matrix of the controlled plant was calculated and employed in RPC. Maddaloni et al. (2011) proposed that a feed-forward inverse transfer function compensation method as a key technique was employed to obtain the best waveform replication results. Cheng and James (2009a,b) developed an inverse compensation to minimize the effect of actuator delay in a real-time hybrid simulation. Lee et al. (2007) employed an acceleration inverse transfer function of the shaking table to cancel out the dynamic characteristics of the shaking table acceleration closed-loop system. Iterative compensation through repetitive excitations (Cuyper and Verhaegen, 2002; Plummer, 2010; Tagawa and Kajiwara, 2007) has been widely used in the shaking table control system. In order to extend the EHST acceleration closed-loop system frequency bandwidth and to improve the stability of the EHST control system, a three variable controller (TVC) (Tagawa and Kajiwara, 2007; Xu et al., 2008) including feed-forward controller and feedback controller was also employed in EHST acceleration closed-loop system as a basic servo controller. The idea behind the TVC is to cancel out the unwanted EHST dynamics and replace them with the designer’s own desired dynamics (Zhang et al., 2005). In order to reduce a number of tuned parameters and to obtain better the tracking accuracy of the TWR, Shen et al. (2010) proposed an equivalent principle between the TVC feed-forward controller and the position closed-loop inverse model of the EHST servo system based on the TVC feedback controller. These feed-forward inverse compensation control strategies, which present some specific advantages: (a) the effect of the feed-forward controller is restricted to the input channel to which it is added (Goele and Swevers, 2010), and (b) the system stability will not be affected by the feed-forward controller on the condition that feed-forward controller design is its own stability, and disadvantages: (a) repetitive excitations may be break the specimen before it is subjected to the desired excitation level (Uchiyama et al., 2009), (b) the system uncertainty and modeling error between the estimated model and the actual plant will influence the tracking accuracy of the TWR and the performance of the feed-forward inverse controller is very sensitive to modeling error or uncertainty, and (c) the estimated inverse transfer function may be mismatch with the actual plant during real-time testing when some factors influence it. Therefore, how to improve the identification accuracy of the estimated inverse transfer function is critical.

An inverse model can be obtained using two ways: (a) invert the plant model or derived forward model and (b) directly identify the inverse model using experimental input-output data set (Luh and Wu, 2000). There are also several common algorithms to estimate the inverse transfer function such as recursive least squares (RLS) (Rigney et al. 2010), adaptive inverse control algorithm (Widrow, 1990), H1 estimator (Cuyper and Verhaegen, 2002), state space model (Cuyper and Verhaegen, 2002), etc. However, the estimated discrete-time transfer function may be a nonminimum phase (NMP) system using autoregressive moving average (ARMA) model and its inverse may be unstable. For NMP systems, the stable implementation of the feed-forward inverse controller is non-causal. To overcome this problem, an adaptive finite impulse response (FIR) was employed in Sharq (2005) and Shen et al. (2010). Rigney et al. (2010) relied on an RLS parameter estimation algorithm to estimate the closed-loop dynamics, and then used the zero-order Taylor series approximate inverse technique to synthesize an inverse system. In this paper, in order to solve the problem, the dead time of identified model is removed.

Some adaptive inverse control approaches are employed for TWR because the payload dynamics are unknown and may change the EHST or shaker frequency response. Karshenas et al. (2000) used an adaptive inverse control algorithm for shock testing. Nobari et al. (1997) also employed adaptive inverse control for vibration test products and presented that the adaptive inverse control approach was a suitable control technique in a nonlinear application such as vibration testing. Some combined control strategies were also used to improve the tracking accuracy in electro-hydraulic servo system. Cuyper et al. (2003) and Vaes et al. (2007) combined the off-line iteration with a feedback controller using H∞ theory for multi-axis test rigs; Gizatullin and Edge (2006) combined theinverse model with a velocity Minimal Control Synthesis (MCS) algorithm for a multi-axis hydraulic test rig and Shen et al. (2011a) proposed a combinedcontrol strategy, which employed a feed-forward inverse transfer function and an MCS algorithm to control the EHST position closed-loop system. Uchiyama et al. (2009) developed an adaptive filter based on H∞ filter and two degree-of-freedom (dof) controller for an electrodynamic shaker. In order to improve the convergence rate of the adaptive inverse control, Shen et al. (2010, 2011b) proposed a combined control strategy, which combined the merits of a feed-forward inverse model and online adaptive inverse control, but modeling error or uncertainty were not taken into account. Plett (2002, 2003) presented an adaptive inverse control approach, which comprised three processes: adaptive system identification, adaptive control of the dynamic response of the system and adaptive disturbance canceling based on internal model control (IMC).

In this paper, a combined control approach with a feed-forward inverse transfer function compensation method, a simple IMC and a two d.f. real-time feedback controller is proposed for EHST acceleration closed-loop system. This method utilizes a feed-forward inverse control of EHST acceleration closed-loop system for extending the EHST system frequency bandwidth and obtaining asymptotic reference tracking, and employs an IMC and a two d.f. real-time feedback controller to minimize the effect of the modeling error or uncertainty.

The contribution is organized as follows. Section 2 describes the used EHST experimental system and its mathematical model. Section 3 designs the servo control system of EHST and further proposes a combined control scheme. EHST acceleration closed-loop system model and its inverse model are estimated in Section 4. Simulation and experimental results are also given in this Section. The experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed control strategy. Section 5 concludes the main points and contributions.

sec.title: 2. Electro-hydraulic shaking table (EHST) experimental system and its dynamic model
2.1. EHST experimental system
sec.p:
Figure 2 shows the EHST experimental system that is employed for the experiments described in this paper and the proposed control strategy is implemented in the real-time EHST experimental system. The structure of the experimental EHST system consists of a double ended hydraulic actuator and a flow-control valve manufactured by Moog, Inc (G761–3004) shown as in Figure 3.The actuator has an 80 mm bore and a 60 mm rod and the servo-valve is a second stage valve with a 38 l/min flow capacity at 7 MPa supply pressure. The relevant technical specifications of the EHST system are presented in Table 1. Figure 2.
The real-time experimental system of an electro-hydraulic shaking table. Figure 3.
Block schematic of the experimental electro-hydraulic shaking table system. Table 1.
Main parameters of EHST
Description Major specification
Size 1.5 m × 1.5 m
Payload 1000 kg
Driving type Electro-hydraulic servo control
Control type Acceleration and position
The range of work frequency 1 Hz∼50 Hz
Actuator stroke ±75 mm
Maximum velocity 0.5 m/s
Maximum vertical acceleration 2 g
EHST: electro-hydraulic shaking table.

The control current signal of the position closed-loop is used to perform the position control of the EHST system, which is directly inputted to the electro-hydraulic servo-valve. A linear variable differential transformer (LVDT) is attached on each hydraulic actuator to measure each actuator’s displacement for indicating the displacement of each actuator piston rod position, and the acceleration is measured with an accelerometer mounted on the drive rod of the table shown as in Figure 3. The time domain drive signal is calculated by the controller based on error signal e and is sent to the electro-hydraulic servo-valve by means of DA board PCL-726 that transforms digital signal into analogue signal. The measured displacement and acceleration signals are acquired by AD board PCL-816, transforming analogue signal into digital signal, using feedback signals to match the reference signals. The objective of control is to keep the acceleration measured signal of the EHST acceleration closed-loop system following the desired acceleration command signal as closely as possible. The implementation of these digital controllers are conducted on xPC target based on MATLAB/Simulink rapid prototyping, which can provide a high-performance, host-target prototyping environment that enables Simulink and Stateflow models to be connected to physical systems and executed in real time on PC-compatible hardware (Huyanan and Sims, 2007; Shen et al. 2008). The sampling interval of the digital controller for EHST is selected as 1000 Hz.

sec.title: 2.2. Dynamic model
sec.p: The differential equations governing the dynamics of the actuator are given in Plummer (2008) for a symmetric actuator as follows: (1)QL=Cdwxvps-xv|xv|pLρ where, QLis load flow and is defined as QL=(Q1+Q2)/2,Cd is the discharge coefficient,wis the constant area gradient of the servo-valve orifices, ρ is themass density of the fluid, Ps is hydraulic supply pressure, PL is load pressure and is defined as PL=P1-P2.

Load flow depends on the servo-valve spool displacementxvand the load pressurePL. Linearized the load flow can be expressed as: (2)QL=Kqxv-KcPL where, Kq is linearized flow gain coefficient, Kc is flow-pressure coefficient and (Gizatullin and Edge, 2006) Kq=∂QL∂xv=CdwPs-PLρKc=∂QL∂PL=CdwxvPs-PLρ2(Ps-PL)

Load flow QL from the servo-valve into actuator chambers can be formulated using the flow continuity equation as follows (3)QL=Apdydt+CtcPL+KVβdPLdt where, Ap is effective area of the cylinder,yis piston displacement and dy/dt is the velocity of the actuator piston, Ctc is total leakage coefficient of actuator and is comprised of internal leakage coefficient Cip and externalleakage coefficient Cep, and is defined as Ctc=Cip+Cep/2, KVβ is the compress flow coefficient, and is defined as KVβ=Vt/4βe and Vt is total volume of the actuator two chambers, and is defined as, Vt=V1+V2, βeis effective bulk modulus.

The hydraulic actuator motion can be (note interval too large) describedusing the following equation with negligible friction: (4)ApPL=md2ydt2+Bcdydt where, m is mass of piston and load and Bc is viscous damping coefficient of the piston and payload.

Performing Laplace transformation from equation (2) to equation (4), a block diagram for the linearized hydraulic actuator dynamics is shown in Figure 4. The transfer functionGp(s) from the spool displacement of the main-stage valve xv to the displacement y of the hydraulic actuator, can be written as follows (5)Gp(s)=yxv=ApKqKLs(mKVβs2+mKces+Ap 2+BcKce) where, Kce is total flow-pressure coefficient and is defined asKce=Kc+Ctc. Figure 4.
Block diagram model for hydraulic actuator.

Rewriting equation (5), we obtain: (6)Gp(s)=yxv=K0s(s2ωh 2+2ζhsωh+1) where, K0 is servovalve flow gain and is defined as K0=ApKqKL/(Ap 2+BcKce), ωh is natural angular frequency of hydraulic actuator and can be represented as ωh=4βe(Ap 2+BcKce)Vtm, ζh is damping ratio of hydraulic actuator and can be represented as

sec.title: 3.1. Three variable controller (TVC)
sec.p:
The TVC is a commonly used controller for shaking tables (Tagawa and Kajiwara, 2007). The three state variables controlled by the TVC are displacement, velocity and acceleration. A block diagram of the TVC is given in Figure 5. The system we wish to control is labelled the controlled Gp(s) with negligible dynamics of the servo-valve. TVC is a two dof controller. The TVC feedback states, including displacement feedback signalyd measured by LVDT, acceleration feedback signal yameasured by accelerometer mounted on the table, and velocity feedback signal yv synthesized from the measured displacement using a low-pass-filter (LPF) and the measured acceleration using high-pass-filter (HPF) (Tagawa and Kajiwara, 2007), is used to improve the stable performance of the EHST. TVC feed-forward states, including Rd, Rv and Ra are generated by a reference signal generator, can extend acceleration frequency bandwidth and can improve tracking performance. The reference signal generator (Ref_signal_generator in Figure 5) takes thedesired acceleration reference signal to generate the three reference states Rd, Rv and Ra, which are used asthe feed-forward signals gains of TVC. The transfer function of the reference signal generator can be expressed (Shen et al., 2010) (7)GAR(s)=Rdxa=Kus2+v0s+d0=Kud0(s2ω0 2+2ζ0ω0s+1) where, d0=ω0 2,v0=2ζ0ω0,Rd is reference position, xa(k) is reference acceleration, Kuis acceleration gain, ζ0 is damping ratio of acceleration control, ω0 is original frequency of acceleration. Figure 5.
Block diagram of TVC controller.
The transfer function Gd(s), from displacement time drive signal Rdi to the displacement output response yd of the hydraulic actuator, can be written as follows: (8)

The desired Gd(s) can be expressed as (Shen et al., 2010) (9)Gd(s)=1(sωr+1)(s2ωnc 2+2ξncωncs+1) where ωr is desired frequency bandwidth of acceleration response, ωncis defined as ωnc=1.2ωh, and ξnc=0.7.

In order to increase the frequency bandwidth of acceleration output response to the desired value ωr,making equation (8) equal to equation (9). So, three parameters in the TVC feedback controller can be calculated as following (10){Kdf=ωrωnc 2K0ωh 2Kvf=Kdf(1ωr+2ξncωnc)-1K0Kaf=Kdf(2ξncωncωr+1ωnc 2)-2ξhK0ωh

The TVC feed-forward controller is used to further extend the acceleration frequency bandwidth and to improve tracking performance by canceling the system pole at ωnc. Thus, the following equation can be obtained (Shen et al., 2010). (11)F(s)=Kdr+Kvrs+Kars2=s2ωnc 2+2ξncωncs+1
The three parameters of TVC feed-forward controller can be calculated by combining equation (10) with equation (11). (12){Kdr=Kdf=ωrωnc 2K0ωh 2Kvr=Kdr2ξncωncKar=Kdrωnc 2

The six parameters of TVC can be calculated according to equations (10) and (12). The TVC feedback controller is introduced to ensure the stability of the controlled system by tuning three feedback gains (Kdf,KvfandKaf).

The TVC (remove however) feed-forward controller is usedtoimprove the frequency bandwidth of theEHSTsystem by tuning three feed-forward gains(Kdr,KvrandKar). However, the TVC controller is used to compensate tracking error based on a priori knowledge and it is not required to compensate the large hydraulic servo-valve gain variations and nonlinearities (Thomas and Donald, 1997). In order to reduce a number of tuned parameters and to obtain a better tracking accuracy, Shen et al. (2010) proposed an equivalent principle between the TVC feed-forward controller and the position closed-loop inverse model based on the TVC feedback controller. The proposed equivalent method can be represented by the block diagram in Figure 6, where Gd(s) is the position transfer function of the real plant tuned by TVC feedback controller, a designed position closed-loop inverse transfer function G∧d -1(z) is the inverse of the estimated modelGd(z), andGd(z) is the z-transform of the transfer function G∧d(z). The G∧d -1(z) modifier on both G∧d -1(z) and G∧d(z) indicates that these quantities are estimated and not theexact inverse and model ofGd(z), respectively. Itcan be observed that the inverse model (G∧d -1(z)) of position closed-loop system (G∧d(z)) is employed to replace theTVC feed-forward controller and its threefeed-forward gains (Kdr,KvrandKar) need not be tuned. A simplified controller is illustrated in Figure 6(b). The estimated system model G∧d(z)differs from the actual plantGd(z)and its differences can bedescribed by an uncertainty ΔGd (Cuyper et al., 2003) as represented in the Figure 6(b). The term ΔGd represented additive system uncertainty and estimated model error of G∧d(z). This ΔGd may include parameter uncertainties in Gd(z) and modeling error between G∧d(z) and Gd(z). The following two relationships can be derived from the Figures 5 and 6(b), respectively, where xa(k) represents the reference acceleration command vector, and ya(k) represents the acceleration output response vector of the EHST system. (13)ya(k)=Kuxa(k)d0(s2ω0 2+2ζ0ω0s+1)(sωr+1) (14) As can be seen by the above two formulas, if TVC feed-forward controller can completely eliminate the EHST dynamic characteristic at ωnc, the ya(k)will be influenced by the desired frequency bandwidth ωr; if the ΔGd is zero, thenya(k) will perfectly follow xa(k). But if ΔGd is non-zero, then ya(k) will not perfectly followxa(k). Thus, the proposed equivalent method can reduce three tuned parameters and may be obtain a better tracking accuracy of TWR, but modeling uncertainty and estimated error ΔGd will influence the tracking accuracy. Figure 6.
Proposed equivalent method between the three variable controller feed-forward controller and position closed-loop inverse transfer function based on three variable controller feedback controller, (a) equivalent method, (b) simplified equivalent method.

sec.title: 3.2. Feed-forward inverse model and its identification
3.2.1. Feed-forward inverse model design
sec.p:
Although the proposed equivalent method can reduce a number of tuned parameters and may obtain a better tracking accuracy of the TWR, the EHST acceleration output response ya(k) may not perfectly follow the acceleration command xa(k) due to modeling uncertainty and estimated error ΔGd. Thus, an acceleration feed-forward inverse transfer function compensation approach is employed in the paper to improve the accuracy of the TWR, which the block diagram of the approach for EHST system is given in Figure 7. The acceleration closed-loop discrete inverse transfer function G∧a -1(z) in the figure is estimated by a recursive extended least square (RELS) algorithm, which determines the required closed-loop input Ra. The acceleration closed-loop discrete transfer function Ga(z) of the EHST includes a reference signal generator, a discrete transfer function Gd(z)of the position closed-loop based on the TVC feedback controller and its estimated position inverse transfer function G∧d -1(z). The acceleration feed-forward inverse model G∧a -1(z) converts the acceleration reference signal xa(k) into an appropriate acceleration drive signal Ra to make the acceleration tracking error smaller. Referring to Figure 7, the acceleration closed-loop transfer function Ga(z)can be expressed as equation (14). ΔGa is also defined as an additive modeling uncertainty and estimated modeling error, which is approximate to Ga(z). Thus the acceleration output response ya(k) can be further derived as: (15)ya(k)=(1+ΔGa)xa(k) Figure 7.
Block diagram of acceleration feed-forward inverse control.

As can be seen in the above formula, ΔGa is the onlyuncertainty factor that influences the tracking accuracy of the TWR. Therefore, how to improve the accuracy of the estimated acceleration inverse transfer function is critical.

sec.title: 3.2.2. Adaptive identifier
sec.p: Here we shall be concerned with systems described by a controlled ARMA model (Simon, 1988) (16)A(z-1)y(t)=B(z-1)u(t-k)+C(z-1)ξ(t) where {y(t)} and {u(t)} are the system input and output sequences, {ξ(t)} is a random noise sequence with zero mean and unknown variance, and A(z-1) and B(z-1) are polynomials in the unit backward shift operator z-1,[z-1y(t)=y(t-1)]. These polynomials can be described by (17)A(z-1)=1+a1z-1+…+anaz-na (18)B(z-1)=b0+b1z-1+…+bnbz-nb (19)C(z-1)=1+c1z-1+…+cncz-nc
Assume that the system input–output data {y(t)} and {u(t)} are available, and the noise sequence {ξ(t)} is immeasurable, and the orders na, nb and nc are known and u(t) = 0 and y(t) = 0 as t ≥ 0.
Write equation (16) into least squares form, is (20)y(t)=ϕT(t)θ+ξ(t) where
But ξ(t) in ϕ(t) cannot be measured, so its estimator ξ∧(t) replaces it, is (21)ξ∧(t)=y(t)-y∧(t)=y(t)-ϕ∧T(t)θ∧(t) where,

RELS with a forgetting factor can be expressed as (Cowan, 1985) (22)θ∧(t)=θ∧(t-1)+K(t)[y(t)-ϕ∧T(t)θ∧(t-1)] (23)K(t)=P(t-1)φ∧(t)λ+ϕ∧T(t)P(t-1)ϕ∧(t) (24)P(t)=[λI-K(t)ϕ∧T(t)]P(t-1) where t is the current time index, λ denotes the reciprocal of the exponential weighting factor, P(t) is the inverse correlation matrix at step t and K(t) is the gain vector at step t.

sec.title: 3.3. Proposed combined control strategy
sec.p:
The block diagram of the integrated control system in the paper is shown in Figure 8. The controller consists of three parts: a real-time feedback controller Kb, which is a proportional gain of the error between the reference acceleration command xa(k)and the EHST system acceleration output response ya(k), a simplified IMC, which can be employed to minimize system uncertainty and estimated model error by tuning gain α(0<α<1), an actual plant and its estimated inverse model G∧a -1(z). Based on Figure 8, we find that (25) Then, ya(k) can be further expressed as (26)ya(k)=(1+ΔGa)E+KbG∧a(z)(1+ΔGa)xa(k)+n(k)1+KbG∧a(z)(1+ΔGa) Figure 8.
Block diagram of the integrated controller for the electro-hydraulic shaking table system.
Referring to Figure 8, the variable state E can be derived as (27)E=xa(k)-αya(k)1-α
Substituting the above relation into equation (26), yields (28)
The acceleration output response ya(k) is given as following equation for different condition (29)
Forn(k) = 0, the acceleration tracking error can be written as following based on the equation (29): (30)
The following two inequalities can be obtained based on equation (30) (31) (32)

Notice that in equations (31) and (32), the proposed combined controller can obtain a smaller tracking error compared to other single controller. Therefore, the effectiveness of the proposed combined controller is verified by theory analysis.

sec.title: 4.1. Model and its inversion identification results
sec.p:
At first, the EHST system needs to be tuned for modelidentification and its inverse model design.The TVC feedback controller is used to compensate the EHST system because EHST’s inherent hydraulic dynamic may cause magnitude attenuation and an inevitable phase’s delay in response to the displacement and acceleration command. The designed gains (Kdf,Kvf and Kaf) of the TVC feedback controller arecalculated according to equation (10) and three feed-forward controller gains (Kdr,Kvr and Kar) can easily be deigned using proposed equivalent principle between the TVC feed-forward controller and estimated position closed-loop inverse transfer function G∧d -1(z).However, the actual experimental gains are further tuned as in Table 2, where ω0 and ξ0 are the acceleration signal generator parameters that can be offline designed, Kdr represents the displacement sensor LVDTsensitivity factor and can be calculated as Kdr=±10V/±75mm, Kdr, Kvr and Kar are offline designed based on the proposed equivalent method, Kvf, Kaf, and kdf are online tuned using position step response based on the overshoot and setting time are small as soon as possible. Table 2.
Experimental parameters
Gains Value Units Gains Value Units Gains Value Units
ω0 3.14 rad/s kvr 0.8 Volts/(m/s) kaf 0.05 g/Volts
ξ0 0.6 – kar 0.004 Volts/g kvf 0 (m/s)/Volts
kdr 133.33 Volts/m kdf 12 m/Volts

An identification test is carried out with a 0–60 Hz random position reference signal with Kvf,Kaf, and kdf and a 2–300 Hz random acceleration reference signal with all parameters in Table 2. The position and acceleration reference signal data and measured experimental data are acquired to estimate their model using the RELS algorithm and further to design their inversion model, respectively. In order to find the most optimal position and acceleration model structure and to avoid a problem that the estimated model may be an NMP system, the root mean square (RMS) errors between the measured data and the estimated model with a different delay sampling interval have been compared in Table 3. The identification results are summarized in Table 3, which shows the identified model with a different delay sampling interval using the same position reference signal. RMS value 3.2935 e-4 m is applied as the position input, and the same acceleration reference signal with RMS value 0.9494 g using the TVC feedback and feed-forward controller is used for the acceleration input. Then, the RMS error of displacement and acceleration using a different delay sampling interval are calculated listed in Table 3. Having analyzed the RMS error of displacement and acceleration contained in the Table 3, as observed, the RMS error with different delay sampling interval markedly differs from their delay. This is due to the fact that the different delay sampling interval will influence the phase of the estimated model and as a result there are significant differences among the different delay sampling intervals. Especially, it will decide the NMP or MP system of the estimated model. G∧P5(z) and G∧A3(z) have a smaller RMS error value and there is also an MPsystem. Thus, their inverse model is a stable systemand can be used to compensate the position and acceleration closed-loop of the EHST, respectively. Therefore, the estimated position model G∧P5(z) and acceleration G∧A3(z)are much fitter than the other estimated model. Table 3.
Results of the close-loop transfer function identification for position and acceleration with different delay sampling interval using RELS algorithm (Reference displacement RMS value 3.2935 e-4 m, Reference acceleration RMS value 0.9494g)
Table 4.
Main parameters of simulation model
Parameter Value
Ap 0.0022m2
Bc 10000 N/(m/s)
Kce 2E-11 (m3/s)/Pa
KL 5623.3 V/m
Kq 0.0017 (m3/s)/V
KVβ 1.5295E-12 m3/Pa
m 1000 kg

Figures 9(a) to (d) present the comparison of the experimental, estimated model (G∧P5(z) and G∧A3(z)) and their inverse transfer function frequency characteristics of EHST. These frequency characteristic are calculated from the reference input to the EHST or estimated model/inverse model output response using the ‘tfestimate’ command in MATLAB. The measured signals are smoothed using a Hanning window in order to minimize the problem of leakage. It can be seen from Figure 9 that G∧P5(z) and G∧A3(z)can compensate the effect of the position and acceleration experimental magnitude and phase. Thus, G∧P5(z) and G∧A3(z)are chosen as the position model and acceleration model, respectively. However, there is a significant discrepancy between the measured and model phase in the Figure 9(d), because the EHST actual acceleration system is an NMP system due to system delay. The simulation model cannot completely replicate simulation of the EHST actual acceleration system, especially in the the system delay model. So there is a significant error between the simulation model phase, the designed inverse model phase and the actual EHST system phase. The significant discrepancy may cause a significant mismatch between the simulation results and experimental results. However, the simulation is only employed to verify the effectiveness of the proposed combined control strategy and is not used to replace the EHST actual system. Therefore, this problem cannot impact on the simulation and experimental results. Figure 9.
Experimental, estimated model and its inversion frequency characteristic of the electro-hydraulic shaking table.

sec.title: 4.2. Simulation verification
sec.p:
In this section, in order to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed control strategy, simulation is carried out based on the plant model presented in Section 2. The simulation is verified by position closed-loop mode and acceleration closed-loop mode. Numerical values are given in Table 4 for servo-valve model and hydraulic actuator model. Figure 10 presents the comparison of the experimental and simulated model magnitude frequency property of the EHST system. Obviously, these results indicate that the experimental system and simulated model match well, which meets the simulated requirement using the hydraulic actuator model. The position and acceleration closed-loop inverse model G∧P5 -1(z) and G∧A3 -1(z)as the feed-forward inverse compensation model can be expressed as equations (33) and (34), respectively (33) (34) Figure 10.
Experimental, simulation model and designed inversion frequency characteristic of electro-hydraulic shaking table position closed-loop. Table 5.
Experimental results of the RMS and its error analysis for acceleration with different controllers
Different controllers Input (g(RMS)) Output (g(RMS)) Error(g(RMS)) (RMS%)
TVC 0.7971 0.8143 0.0172 2.16
IM 0.7971 1.116 0.3189 40.01
Proposed 0.7971 0.9893 0.1922 24.11
RMS: root mean square.

According to the block diagram of Figure 8, compensating means to improve the tracking accuracy of a transient waveform replication by multiplying it with the inverse transfer function G∧d -1(z) and G∧A3 -1(z) of the position and acceleration to generate the time domain drive command, respectively. However, owing to the system uncertainties and estimated modeling error, the achieved position and acceleration output response yd(k) and ya(k) could not perfectly match the desired position command xd(k)and acceleration command xa(k). The performance among three controllers is compared, (1) a feed-forward inverse model compensation with the designed inverse model G∧P5 -1(z) and G∧A3 -1(z) (IM), (2) combined the (1) with an improved internal model control (IM+IMC,α = 0.5 for position mode, α = 0.25 for acceleration mode), and (3) the proposed controller combined (2) with real-time feedback controller (IM+IMC+RTFC, α = 0.5, Kb = 1 for positionmode, α = 0.25for acceleration mode; α = 0.25, Kb = 0.05 for position mode, α = 0.25 for acceleration mode;). The integral absolute error (ITAE) (Karshenas et al., 2000) graphs, as depicted in Figure 11, provide a better indication of the different controller performance, where ITAE is given by (35)ITAE=∑i=1 N|ei|/N∑i=1 N|ri|/N×100 % where, N is the sample length, ei is position or acceleration tracking error, ri is position or acceleration reference signal. Figure 11.
Comparisons of three different payloads via the integral absolute error.

The three ITAE graphs in Figure 11 show the three different controller output responses. The larger payload change related to m = 5000 kg, the system uncertainty and modeling error will be larger. These ITAE results indicate that the proposed combined control scheme has performed best among these controllers. The figure verified the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme.

sec.title: 4.3. Experimental results
sec.p:
In this section, the results of two kinds of transient waveform replication, e.g. classical shock waveform and seismic synthesis waveform, are presented and discussed. The objective of classical shock waveform testing is to reproduce the user defined reference shock pulse. A shock experiment is carried out in order to verify whether the proposed control strategy can be used for transient waveform replication or not. In shock testing, a problem (Karshenas et al., 2000), in which the initial and final acceleration, velocity and displacement magnitudes must all be zero, needs to be solved. So, a pre-sawtooth shock with pre-pulse, post-pulse and main-pulse (20 ms) is designed and the total areas of the shock equal to zero. For this experiment, the designed pre-sawtooth shock was used to excite the EHST system. The TVC controller, feed-forward inverse model method, combined feed-forward inverse model with simple IMC, and a proposed combined control scheme were employed as different controllers. Figure 12 shows the different acceleration output response of the EHST system under the four different controllers. As can be seen, the EHST output follows the reference pre-sawtooth shock very closely with the proposed control scheme. Figure 12.
Classical shock waveform replication results with different control schemes.

The Seismic Synthesis application generates acceleration waveforms whose calculated shock response spectra meet the specified reference response spectra. Howto generate a transient random waveform that matches the prescribed reference response spectrum (RRS) within specified match criteria is a key technique for seismic synthesis waveform. The waveform synthesis and convergence process includes the following general steps:
Convert the RRS to an equivalent power spectral density (PSD) function and Fourier magnitude spectrum according to the following equations
(36)S(ω)≈-ζπωSRRS 2(ω)/ln(-ζπtlnp) (37)A(ω)=[4S(ω)Δω] where S(ω) is calculated power PSD, SRRS(ω) is RRS, ζ is damping ratio, t is desired waveform time, p is probability coefficient that is defined as the average magnitude of the shock response spectrum (SRS) not exceeding the average magnitude of the RRS, A(ω) is Fourier magnitude spectrum of calculated PSD, Δω is frequency interval and is defined as Δω=2πf/l(FFT), where f is sampling frequency, l(FFT) is the length of the Fourier magnitude spectrum.
Compute a random phase sequence for the Fourier spectrum and compute the inverseof the Fourier spectrum to produce a random waveform.a(t)
(38)a(t)=IFFT[A(ω)eiφ(ω)] where a(t) is generated random waveform, IFFT(·) presents the inverse of the Fourier spectrum, ϕ(ω) is phase spectrum.
Calculate the SRS of the generated random a(t) wave format each Fourier magnitude spectrum and compare this calculated SRS to the reference RRS. If the maximum error between the SRS of the generated random waveform and RRS is within the smallest tolerance value of the RRS, then proceed to the next step; otherwise, modify the spectral magnitudes of the Fourier spectrum according the equation (38) and return to step 2. If convergence fails, control returns to step 2 where a new phase sequence is computed.
(39)Ak+1(ω)=Ak(ω)SRRS(ω)SGRS_k(ω) where Ak+1(ω) and Ak(ω) are Fourier magnitude spectrum of calculated PSD at k + 1 and k step, respectively, SGRS_k(ω) is the SRS of the generated random waveform a(t) at step.

Figure 13 is the defined RRS and the generated random waveform a(t) after several iterations, then the SRS of a(t) is calculated. It can be seen that the calculated SRS closely follows the defined RRS. Thus, the generated random waveform a(t) can be employed as desired random signal of the RRS to excite the EHST system. Figure 13.
Reference response spectrum and its seismic synthesis waveform.

In order to verify the proposed control scheme performance, this experiment describes the replication of the generated random signal a(t), which is carried out using different controllers to the EHST system. The tracking performance among three different controllers is compared, e.g. (1) conventional TVC, (2) feed-forward inverse model compensate method, and (3) the proposed combined control scheme. Comparison among the EHST output acceleration response using the three different controllers with the generated random signal a(t) are shown in Figure 14. The SRS of the different controllers’ acceleration output response of the Figure 14 are given in Figure 15.

The acceleration RMS and its error of Figure 15 were also listed in Table 5. It can be observed that the generated random waveform a(t) is accurately followed and the SRS of a(t) is also closely matched using the proposed control scheme. The root mean square (RMS) error is from approximately 40.01% with the feed-forward inverse model compensation to 24.11% with the proposed combined control strategy (in Table 5). In fact, the acceleration output response with the TVC controller cannot reach the acceleration command, but RMS% error can better reach the ideal value than the other controller due to some high-frequency oscillation added in the acceleration output response, which can be certified by Figures 14 and 15. So, the RMS% error for the TVC control in Table 5 is 2.16%, which is less than that for the proposed control strategy (24.11%). By comparing these experimental results, the tracking ability to the reference signal is shown to achieve a good performance when the proposed combined control scheme is employed.

Therefore the effectiveness of the proposed combined control scheme is also verified by seismic synthesis waveform replication experimental of the EHST system. Figure 14.
Seismic synthesis waveform replication results with different controllers. Figure 15.
The shock response spectrum of measured seismic synthesis waveform with different controllers.

sec.title: 5. Conclusions
sec.p: In this study, an EHST is conducted to verify the transient waveform tracking performance. A combined control strategy is presented in order to extend the frequency bandwidth of the EHST system and improve the tracking performance. In order to reduce a number of tuned parameters and to obtain a better tracking accuracy, an equivalent principle between the TVC feed-forward controller and position closed-loop inverse transfer function based on the TVC feedback controller is proposed. The proposed control strategy combined the merits of a feed-forward inverse model, an internal model control and a real-time feedback controller. Different delay sampling intervals are compared because the identified position and acceleration transfer function of the EHST system may be an NMP system using the RELS algorithm. To show the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme, real experiments were evaluated the signal replication fidelity of the EHST system. A number of experiments were carried out on an actual EHST system. The performance of the proposed control strategy was evaluated and compared to examine its effectiveness in the EHST system. Experimental results demonstrated that the reference signal and EHST output response signal match well, which meets the EHST system time waveform replication experiment requirement. The effectiveness of the proposed control strategy was verified via these simulated and experimental results. Consequently, the proposed control strategy not only can be utilized with the single axis EHST waveform replication but can also be employed as a basis for a multi-axis EHST control system. It is also worth noting that the proposed combined strategy can also be extended to other control systems.
